string-array.name: lesson_1
string-array.item: To print a string in java, you need to use System.out.println(“String”).
Example:
• Its output:
Hello, world!
• Console window: Text box into which the program\'s output is printed.

string-array.name: lesson_2
string-array.item: There are 8 simple types in java.
int: The integer type, with range -2,147,483,648 . . . 2,147,483,647 of size 4 bytes
byte: The type describing a single byte, with range -128 . . . 127 of size 1 byte
short: The short integer type, with range -32768 . . . 32767 of size 2 bytes
long: The long integer type, with range -9,223,372,036,854,775,808 . . . -9,223,372,036,854,775,807 of size 8 bytes
double: The double-precision floating-point type, with a range of about ±10308 and about 15 significant decimal digits of size 8 bytes
float: The single-precision floating-point type, with a range of about ±1038 and about 7 significant decimal digits of size 4 bytes
char: The character type, representing code units in the Unicode encoding scheme of size 2 bytes
boolean: The type with the two truth values false and true of size 1 byte

string-array.name: lesson_3
string-array.item: • A variable can be declared and initialized in one statement
• Once given a value, a variable can be used in expressions:
• You can assign a value more than once:

string-array.name: lesson_4
string-array.item: Increment and decrement
Shortcuts to increase or decrease a variable\'s value by 1 using unary operators (++ and --)
Shorthand :variable++; Equivalent longer version variable = variable + 1;
Shorthand :variable--;Equivalent longer version variable = variable - 1;

string-array.name: lesson_5
string-array.item: • Char:A primitive data type representing single characters of text(e.g ‘a’,’b’,’@’,…)
• "h" is a String, but \'h\' is a char (they are different)
A variable of type String is different from the other (primitive) data types we’ve seen so far,It is actually a reference to a String object.
Examples:
#c String str = "hello there!";\nint len = str.length(); //Take the size of the string\nString first = str.substring(0, 1);//Take the first element of the string

string-array.name: lesson_6
string-array.item: x Less than y True if x is less than y, otherwise false.
x Greater than y True if x is greater than y, otherwise false.
x Less than or equal to y True if x is less than or equal to y, otherwise false.
x Greater than or equal to y True if x is greater than or equal to y, otherwise false.
x Equal y True if x equals y, otherwise false.
x Not Equal y True if x is not equal to y, otherwise false.
From highest precedence to lowest:
1)unary operators: ++,--,+,-
2)multiplicative operators: *,/,%
3)additive operators: +,-
4)relational operators: <,>,<=,>=
5)equality operators: ==,!=
6)assignement operators: =,+=,-=,*=,/=,%=

string-array.name: lesson_7
string-array.item: The body of if statement may consist of multiple statements that must be executed in sequence whenever the condition is true.
These statements must be grouped together to form a block statement by enclosing them in braces { }
• Different types of statements:

string-array.name: lesson_8
string-array.item: • Loop statements allow repeatedly executing a statement or a sequence of statements one or more times as long as some condition remains true.
• There are three loop statements in Java
– for loop statement, while loop statement, do-while loop statement
#c for (int i = 1; i <= 4; i++) { // repeat 4 times\n System.out.println("I am so smart");//This will be printed 4 times.\n}
Nested for loop example:

string-array.name: lesson_9
string-array.item: • scope: The part of a program where a variable exists.
– From its declaration to the end of the { } braces
• A variable declared in a for loop exists only in that loop.
• A variable declared in a method exists only in that method.
Scope implications
• A variable can\'t be declared twice or used out of its scope.
• Variables without overlapping scope can have same name.

string-array.name: lesson_10
string-array.item: Declaring a method
#c public static void name() {\n statement;\n}
• Example:
– Output:
This product causes cancer\nin lab rats and humans.

string-array.name: mcq_1
string-array.item: Exercise:\nFind the correct code between the following java programs:
If we are using a two digits number in our code, which primitive type is the best to use to save memory.

#c String hannah = "Did Hannah see bees? Hannah did.";\n• What is the value displayed by the expression hannah.length()? And what is the element display by the expression String s=Hannah.substring(0,1);

string-array.name: choices_1
string-array.item: A: public class Bug2 {...},B: class public Bug3 {...},C: Bug4 public clas {...} ,D: class Bug6 {}
A: int,B: byte,C: short,D: char
A: true;false;true;true;true,B: true;false;false;true;false,C: true;false;true;true;false,D: false;false;true;true;true
A: A,B: BCD,C: ABD,D: ABCD
A: No error,B: Overlapping scope,C: Element outside the scope,D: Overlapping scope and element outside the scope
A: BCBDA,B: ADBCB,C: ABCBD,D: BCADB

string-array.name: answer_1
string-array.item: d
b
c
c
a
